607fb245-ed10-4f28-bbc0-24786131ce7c.description: This badge is awarded to individuals who complete the Academic Program and Evaluation Management (APEM) certification program. This program provides learners with an understanding of the data, systems, and processes needed to make well-informed and broadly supported program decisions consistent with an institution’s mission, academic standards, markets and program economics.
607fb245-ed10-4f28-bbc0-24786131ce7c.name: Academic Program Evaluation and Management

badge_template_activities.title: Participants will: learn concepts, information, & tasks needed to make data-informed program decisions; learn to complete an academic portfolio evaluation, including finding, analyzing, and synthesizing relevant data & evaluation criteria; grasp the keys to effective decision-making processes for current & new programs; learn the mechanics of Integrated Program Analysis, program evaluation software, & program portfolio workshops, as well as the overall art & science of academic entrepreneurship.

dc037048-e1f9-4f2c-bdf4-fb6d06e9e637.description: A Bay Path University student is able to effectively and responsibly use information by utilizing various modes of technology to support, foster, and connect learning across the entire educational experience. Earners of this badge are evaluated in four categories: Functional Skills, Creativity & Critical Thinking, Digital Citizenship, and Communication & Collaboration.
dc037048-e1f9-4f2c-bdf4-fb6d06e9e637.name: Technologically Resourceful - Gold Level

badge_template_activities.title: Earners submit their evidence to an expert in Technology that who evaluates the evidence for competency. For the Gold level of this badge, earners have met the following criteria:
Earners demonstrate exceptional mastery of functional skills by using multiple digital content design tools to create a digital project.
Earner projects are original, well organized, easily navigated, aesthetically pleasing, well designed, and artistic. They also have 5 or more interactive elements and 4 or more modes of interaction.

Earners demonstrate exemplary understanding of digital safety, etiquette, rights, and responsibilities, as well as demonstrating a deep understanding of the cultural and social implications of technology.
Earner projects demonstrate an extensive use of collaborative web-based platforms and projects are highly accessible and designed with the end user in mind.

77f3d79b-0b86-47f2-ab00-694315aa1e87.description: According to the National Association of Colleges and Employers, Career Competencies are defined as the attainment and demonstration of requisite competencies that broadly prepare college graduates for successful transition into the workplace. The Career Readiness Badge addresses three main skill categories associated with preparing for a career. They are: Digital Presentation & Professional Identity; Networking & Relationship Building; and Lifelong Learning & Reflection.

1f88e7a2-eca8-46cc-a842-2e3aadfef86d.description: Emotional Intelligence is the capability of individuals to recognize their own emotions and those of others, discern between different feelings and label them appropriately, use emotional information to guide thinking and behavior, and manage/adjust emotions to adapt to environments or achieve one's goal(s). The Emotional Intelligence Badge is composed of four main skill categories: HEAR: Active Listening and Curiosity; THINK & FEEL: Diverse Perspectives; SEE: Action; SAY & DO: Change Intentions
1f88e7a2-eca8-46cc-a842-2e3aadfef86d.name: Emotional Intelligence - Gold Level

badge_template_activities.title: Earners submit their evidence to an expert in Emotional Intelligence who then evaluates the evidence for competency. For the Gold level of this badge, earners possess a high ability to attend to others in the following areas:
HEAR: Active Listening and Curiosity- Earner completes active listening role play exercise using Stand Out . Earner completes journal reflection work for their role play exercise.

THINK & FEEL: Diverse Perspectives - Earner completes the Empathy 360 assessment. Earner submits a journal entry with Insights, Questions, and Implications (IQI) to reflect on assessment results. Earner produces a gap analysis to help make sense of how they viewed themselves and others viewed them through the assessment.Earner reflects on Resource Center videos and articles. Earner successfully completes Finding Another Perspective workbook and submits reflection.

SEE: Action - Earner completes the 3 components of the Empathy Journal (Empathy Detective, Resource Overview, Critical Thinking IQI's) which builds a journey of evidence that reflects personal exploration of empathy.

SAY & DO: Change Intentions - Earner completes a 2-3 page Empathy Reflection; either done in a document or a recorded video submission on Stand Out. Earner submits a final paper that is a program design to implement a program at their organization/friends/family to engage others in an empathy journey.

8e4570ea-af28-4f86-bc4d-692692ca3ec0.description: Earners of this badge can demonstrate they are skilled in defining their own ethical stance, can thoughtfully consider an ethical dilemma, understand the difference between morals, ethics, and laws, and are aware of intercultural ethical differences.
8e4570ea-af28-4f86-bc4d-692692ca3ec0.name: Ethical Reasoning - Gold Level

badge_template_activities.title: Earners submit their evidence to an expert in Ethical Reasoning who then evaluates the evidence for competency. For the Gold level of this badge, students have met the following criteria:

Earners can articulate their ethical stance and are clear about its authoritative sources. They can identify the authoritative source of their ethical stance and can recognize the limitations of their ethical stance.
Earners can define ethical reasoning and can articulate the ethical stance of others. They demonstrate that they can suggest a path of action given these differing ethics.

Earners can describe the importance of ethical reasoning in an organization. They can articulate examples of short- and long-term problems that emerge from a lack of ethical reasoning as well as can specify how ethical reasoning can be cultivated in an organization.

Earners can define an ethical dilemma by identifying the different ethical stances of relevant stakeholders in a case presented and explaining why it leads to an ethical dilemma. In addition they can articulate a potential path to resolution of the dilemma for the case.

Earners demonstrate that they understand the differences among the moral, ethical, and legal and are able to articulate how conflicts can occur between the moral and the legal. Earners provide an international example of how moral and legal matters vary between two nations.
